thread.title: AustralianSuper posts third year of double-digit returns, but tips dream run to end
thread.title_full: AustralianSuper posts third year of double-digit returns, but tips dream run to end | afr.com

author: Sally Rose
title: AustralianSuper posts third year of double-digit returns, but tips dream run to end
text:
AustralianSuper's chief investment officer Mark Delaney: "It is unlikely super fund members will get a fourth consecutive year of double-digit returns." Arsineh Houspian Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Sally Rose The country's largest superannuation fund, which covers more than one in 10 Australian workers, has delivered a third consecutive year of double-digit growth for holders of its balanced option, but its chief investment officer is tipping the dream run to end.
AustralianSuper's balanced option - its default option which invests in a wide range of assets including shares, property and bonds - recorded a return of 10.9 per cent for the financial year ended June 30, 2015.
The fund's chief investment officer and deputy chief executive, Mark Delaney, said the strong performance in 2014-15 took total returns over the past three years to 46 per cent, or an average of 13 per cent a year.
"While it was a difficult year in fixed income markets, strength in global property, infrastructure and sharemarkets – combined with a declining Aussie dollar – boosted returns," Mr Delaney said.
Super ratings agency Chant West has estimated that the median return from balanced funds over the financial year ended June 2015 will be 9.5 per cent.
Leading asset consultants including Towers Watson, Frontier Advisers and Rice Warner have all warned that major superannuation funds will probably need to lower their targeted investment returns over the next three to 10 years . The weaker investment outlook is a reflection of weak global economic growth, the unwinding of the massive experiment in central banks' quantitative easing, and record-low interest rates in Australia.
"I will be very surprised if we can deliver similar returns over the coming three years, but taking on more risk is not the answer," Mr Delaney said.
AustralianSuper has $92 billion in assets under management and manages retirement savings on behalf of more than 10 per cent of working Australians.
 Mr Delaney said the 16.9 per cent depreciation in the Australian dollar boosted the annual return on AustralianSuper's balanced fund by 12.5 per cent.
"The Aussie has already fallen a lot, but it could still depreciate significantly more in the year ahead if export commodity prices continue to come under pressure and the Reserve Bank cuts rates again. Long term, I think the currency will settle somewhere in the US60¢ range".
Mr Delaney said AustralianSuper completed its annual asset allocation review four weeks ago, and plans to make no significant changes.
"At the margins we have shifted a little bit of money out of shares and put that into property, infrastructure and cash."
The fund is maintaining its strategic asset allocation despite an expectation of lower returns.
The total return to members in the AustralianSuper balanced option over the past five years has been 62.5 per cent, or an average of 10.2 per cent a year. In the years ahead returns are tipped to fall below the 10 year average of 7.3 per cent a year.
Mr Delaney plans to continue bringing more funds management capabilities in-house in a bid to offset lower returns with reduced costs.
When AustralianSuper members get their statement this month it will list an investment management fee of 57 basis points, down from 59 basis points the previous year.
Over the past year AustralianSuper poured more than $2 billion into direct foreign property investments, buying stakes in office buildings in Boston, Washington DC, and Honolulu and the King's Cross redevelopment project in London.
The combined property portfolio posted a return of 10.3 per cent in the year ended June 30, 2015; the infrastructure portfolio delivered 9.7 per cent.
In the equities portfolio Japanese stocks were the star, returning 35.7 per cent. European equities returned 7.6 per cent, US equities 7.4 per cent, and Australian equities 5.6 per cent.
